author: John Hutchinson for MailOnline
title: Man flies 22,778 miles in 72hrs to score air miles for first class trip to Hong Kong
text:
551 shares 66
View
comments
Most would consider a 72-hour plane journey a hellish experience, but one traveller showed that this extreme trip has its benefits - it can earn you enough air miles for a return long-haul first-class ticket.
Kevin Song, from New York, travelled 22,778 miles by air over eight separate journeys at a cost of $3,609.
By the end he had collected enough points to buy a first-class ticket with Cathay Pacific from the U.S. to Hong Kong - usually costing around $28,000.
Mr Song is a frequent flier with American Airlines, and by using their loyalty schemes throughout his journey he accumulated almost 142,000 air miles
As a frequent flier of American Airlines, he used benefits of his membership to book two round-trips, starting out of New York-JFK.
The first journey was booked as a round-trip between New York-JFK and Dublin, and the second was a round-trip booked as Dublin-Honolulu, via Los Angeles.

Share this article Share 551 shares On landing back in the U.S. after only using up half-a-day's holiday, Mr Song had accumulated 141,608 miles.
He now plans to spend the miles travelling from the U.S. to Hong Kong to visit his girlfriend in first class on either on Japan Airlines or Cathay Pacific.
He worked out he had spent $3,609 on all the flights. The cost of a first class flight, according to Mr Song to Hong Kong would set him back around $28,000. However converting the 141,6008 air miles he racked up means he can put them towards this journey.
This map shows just how long Mr Song's cross-Atlantic journey was to accumulate his air miles
Mr Song spent $3,609 on all the flights
Speaking to The Points Guy , Mr Song said: 'My 141,608 miles will get me a round-trip in first class (which costs 67,500 miles each way), or nearly three one-ways in business class (which costs 50,000 miles).
'Cathay Pacific first-class fares are pretty consistent: Right now, the nonstop from JFK to Hong Kong is pricing out at a whopping $28,383.'
Speaking to MailOnline Travel, TravelSupermarket.com expert Bob Atkinson said: 'You need to be a frequent flyer to really make this kind of thing work, he's an American Airlines frequent flyer.
'Essentially the guy has spent money buying tickets and used a range of benefits to minimise the cost of purchase and maximise the way he earns his points PLUS he has protected his ultra-frequent flying rewards status to protect him in the future.
'Those points give him enough to earn a return flight to HK in first with Cathay Pacific - one of the oneWorld partners who American is affiliated with.
'It's a fairly extreme way of flying to achieve what he wanted. It appears he was wanting to protect his flying status with AA rather than accrue the miles, however he has managed both.
'The average punter would not be able to do this as the frequency which most people fly is just not enough to make it worth their while.'
Mr Song is now planning on using his air miles to travel with Cathay Pacific to Hong Kong to see his girlfriend
